title.value: The StatCan Dialogue Dataset: Retrieving Data Tables through Conversations with Genuine Intents
title.justification: Title extracted from the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: The StatCan Dialogue Dataset: Retrieving Data Tables through Conversations with Genuine Intents

extractions.description: This paper introduces the StatCan Dialogue Dataset consisting of over 19,000 conversation turns between Statistics Canada agents and online users. The dataset features genuine intents and is available in English or French. The paper proposes two tasks based on the dataset: automatic table retrieval and response generation. Experiments demonstrate that existing models struggle with these tasks, particularly with generalizing to future conversations.

type.justification: The paper conducts experiments to establish baselines for the proposed tasks, focusing on the performance of models on real-world data.
type.quote: We investigate the difficulty of each task by establishing strong baselines. Our experiments on a temporal data split reveal that all models struggle to generalize to future conversations.

name.justification: The primary research field is Natural Language Processing as the paper focuses on conversational agents and dialogue systems.
name.quote: One of the longstanding goals in Natural Language Processing (NLP) is to develop conversational agents that assist people with concrete tasks.

name.justification: The paper deals with creating and evaluating conversational agents to assist users in retrieving data tables through dialogue.
name.quote: We introduce the StatCan Dialogue Dataset consisting of over 19,379 conversation turns between agents working at Statistics Canada and online users looking for published data tables.

name.justification: One of the two main tasks proposed is automatic retrieval of relevant tables based on ongoing conversations, falling within the field of Information Retrieval.
name.quote: First, we introduce the table retrieval task, which requires a model to predict the table returned by the agent given the messages sent so far.

name.justification: T5 is used for the response generation task in the experiments conducted by the authors.
name.quote: We investigate fine-tuned T5-large models and explore variants where the input is augmented with table titles.

is_contributed.justification: The model T5 is not a contribution in the scope of this paper but is used for baselines.

is_executed.justification: The T5 model was executed as part of the experiments in the paper.
is_executed.quote: We investigate fine-tuned T5-large models and explore variants where the input is augmented with table titles.

is_compared.justification: The model is compared with other models like DPR in the experiments.
is_compared.quote: For both tasks, we investigate its difficulty by establishing strong baselines and evaluating them on various metrics.

referenced_paper_title.value: Exploring the Limits of Transfer Learning with a Unified Text-to-Text Transformer
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper is the original T5 paper by Raffel et al., which introduced the T5 model.

name.justification: The dataset introduced and used in this study is the StatCan Dialogue Dataset consisting of conversations between online users and Statistics Canada agents.
name.quote: We introduce the StatCan Dialogue Dataset consisting of over 19,379 conversation turns between agents working at Statistics Canada and online users looking for published data tables.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper is not applicable as this dataset is introduced by the current study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We introduce the StatCan Dialogue Dataset

name.justification: The HuggingFace Transformers library is used for implementing the transformer models like T5 in the experiments.
name.quote: All models based on the transformer architecture were implemented using HuggingFace’s library (Wolf et al., 2020).

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the original HuggingFace Transformers library paper by Wolf et al., 2020.
referenced_paper_title.quote: All models based on the transformer architecture were implemented using HuggingFace’s library (Wolf et al., 2020).
